conclusion: Shadows are cast when an object blocks light. They appear on the side of the object away from the light source. The length and position of a shadow depend on the position and height of the light source.
In the image, shadows (A, B, C, D) are cast behind the objects, indicating the light source is in front of them.

premise: When the light source moves forward, it gets closer to the objects.
conclusion: The light source moving forward changes the angle of light rays hitting the ground.

premise: The light source moving forward changes the angle of light rays hitting the ground.
conclusion: As the light moves forward, shadows will shift closer to the objects because the light rays will intersect the ground at a steeper angle.

premise: The light source moving forward changes the angle of light rays hitting the ground.
conclusion: As the light moves forward, shadows will shift backward because the light rays will intersect the ground at a shallower angle.

premise: The light source moving forward changes the angle of light rays hitting the ground.
conclusion: The closer the light is to the objects, the shorter and smaller the shadows become due to the increased angle between the light and the horizontal plane.

premise: Shadows A, B, C, and D shift backward and become shorter and smaller as the light source moves forward.
conclusion: When the light source moves forward above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will shift backward and become shorter and smaller.
